gue:

 Message -----

m

seeking more " punishment "
> 
> 
>  =
 I have followed this discussion with great interest and will have 
to go o=
ver it
>   again I'm sure, but I clearly see what Milt is talking about.  T=
o 
find a stiffer
>   deer one would have to go to the tundra...
> 
>   I r=
ecall well a tsuba that I found many years ago.  It was a 
small, copper
> =
  sanmai awase (if I correctly remember a phrase I haven't uttered 
for 15 =
or more
>   years!) with a touch of silver (tin??) showing stylised 
(stamp=
ed?) waves with a
>   creature on it that I always thought was an "over-end=
owed 
rabbit", but Bob
>   Haynes told me was a fox!!  I wrote to Bob when =
I saw a similar 
tsuba in one of
>   his catalogues.  I was amazed when he =
said this was a very early 
style of tsuba
>   ca 1300 - 1400.  I had it fo=
r years, often looking at it and 
saying "Do I like
>   it, or do I not??" =
 Same thing with this deer kinko.  I have 
gazed at Pete
>   Klein's image =
on yahoo (I actually have the Lundren Collection 
book, but it's
>   out on=
 loan to a 'kinko' mate) for a long time on this sleepless 
night, and I
> =
  ask myself the same question all over again.  So David Z, if I 
could ask=
 you a
>   question, when you say "I don't collect kinko at all,  but this =

is one of a
>   small number of cases which, granted a opportunity, would =
lead me 
to alter my
>   policy" I have to ask you "WHY??"  Please explain.=

> 
>   If I found this very tsuba I would think it was junk.  I don't 
hav=
e to tell you
>   why.  Or do I??  The design spilling into the seppadai I =
have 
only seen on tsuba
>   I didn't care for.  The wobbly surface and inc=
redibly bad nanako 
would kill it
>   for me.  And the stiff deer doesn't d=
o anything for me at all.  
However, I would
>   look at the larger than us=
ual kozuka ana and opine "Hmmm, maybe 
it's early".
>   Back to my question=
 to myself "Do I like it, or do I not".  If I 
don't like it,
>   I don't c=
ollect it, no matter what the aesthetes say.
> 
>   Now, this puts me into =
the rustic class, I know, but there is a 
point to this
>   that is not all=
 derisory or derogatory.  It is this.  It is easy 
to pick
>   excellent wo=
rk amongst Edo period tsuba , even in the iron "wabi-
sabi" class,
>   but =
the archaic styles, the transition between (if we might say) 
conceptual
> =
  forerunners and the refined later schools is much, much more 
difficult. =
 Or is
>   it??  Recall here Milt's hawk tsuba that lead to the present 
di=
scussion.  And I
>   can show you a tsuba that a well-educated (tsuba knowl=
edge) mate 
of mine
>   dismissed as "late, possibly 1920s".  It is a maste=
rwork of late 
Edo/early Meiji
>   and belongs to a friend of mine.  If he =
gives permission I'll put 
up some images
>   of it.
> 
>   So, to bring th=
is to a close, are there any others inhabiting the 
same closet as
>   I???=
  I know I'm lacking an ability, an aesthetic if you like, to 
appreciate t=
he
>   stiff deer kinko in question and it worries me.  It seems without 
t=
horough study
>   and training many tsuba in this time frame would indeed b=
e 
considered junk and
>   sold off, possibly to an ignominious fate.  The =
other kinko that 
Pete shows in
>   two images at the same link does "speak=
 to me".  It is from the 
same time frame
>   and I find it elegant and ref=
ined and would collect it.  I think 
this discussion
>   parallels the Sue =
Koto kazuuchimono line of thinking with blades -
 I don't
>   collect those=
 either...
> 
>   Barry Thomas
>   (Melbourne, Australia)
